item.title: Can some one help me figure out what wrong with this code?
item.dc:creator: @JavaLearner JavaLearner
item.description:
@JavaLearner wrote:

Of course it did.

Say you have 28 rune essence in your inventory. Your line is:

You’re saying that you will delete 3 times 1436 in 1 specific slot, however, you only have 1 of them in that specific slot (since they’re not stackable unnoted). So, you can write a for-loop to go through your inventory, and if it has 3, it will add them to the pouch.

Something like

int counter = 0; //basically the same principle as with that startRC that I helped you with
for(int i = 0; i < playerItems.length; i++){
   if(playerHasItemAmount(1436, 1)){
      if(counter == 3)
         break;
      else{
         deleteItem(1436, GetItemSlot(1436), 1);
         counter++;
      }
    }
}

Also, I’m a bit wondered because you seem to able to write this kind of code, but you always say you don’t know what you need to do, even though it’s completely basic. Not trying to be a dick here, but can you try to do some extra things yourself and try to de-bug your code and if you run into trouble again, ask it here. Normally, we shouldn’t just “spoonfeed” it for you so you’ll have less work to do.

Read full topic

}else{
if((playerHasItemAmount(7936, 3) && runeEssStore == false)) {
deleteItem(7936,GetItemSlot(7936), 3);
pureEssStored = true;
}
}

}[/code]

item.source: Can some one help me figure out what wrong with this code?

item.title: Can some one help me figure out what wrong with this code?
item.dc:creator: @JavaLearner JavaLearner
item.description:
@JavaLearner wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:3, topic:509137”]Replace with logical or with an and[/quote]^this:

[code]if(item_id == 5509){
if(!playerHasItemAmount(1436, 3) && !playerHasItemAmount(7936, 3)){ // or if(playerHasItemAmount(1436, 3) == false && playerHasItemAmount(7936, 3) == false){
sendMessage(“I need atleast 3 rune/pure essence.”);
}else
if(playerHasItemAmount(1436, 3)){
deleteItem(1436, GetItemSlot(1436), 3);
runeEssStored = true;
}else{
if(playerHasItemAmount(7936, 3)){
deleteItem(7936,GetItemSlot(7936), 3);
pureEssStored = true;
}
}

}[/code]

You see, using || basically means if your first condition is true OR your second condition is true, execute whatever comes behind that if statement.
In this case:

This basically means if I don’t have 3 pure essence OR if I don’t have 3 rune essence, do:

So even if you have 3 pure essence, but not 3 rune essence, it will still give the message, because ONE of the conditions is true

Now, if you do && instead of ||, you will check both the conditions, even if one of them is correct. With an && both the conditions need to be true in order to execute whatever comes behind it.

So a little summary:

It will execute whatever comes behind it if you do not have 3 pure essence OR 3 rune essence

-> It will only not do it if you have 3 pure essence and 3 rune essence in your inventory

It will execute whatever comes behind it if you do not have 3 pure essence AND do not have 3 rune essence

PS: ! basically means NOT:
In this case: if the player does NOT have 3 rune essence or does NOT have 3 pure essence (if you use || in your statement)

Read full topic
